div.p: Campaſpe, Played beefore the Queenes Maieſtie on newyeares day at night, by her Maieſties Children, and the Children of Paules. (⁂)
¶ Imprinted at London for Thomas Cadman, 1584.

div.head: The Prologue at the Court.
div.p: VVEe are aſhamed that our birde which fluttered by twilight ſeeming a ſwan, ſhould bee proued a Batte ſet againſt the ſunne. But as Iupiter placed Silenus Aſſe among the ſtarres, and Alcebiades couered his pictures beeing Owles and Apes, with a courtaine embroidered with Lions and Eagles, ſo are we enforced vpon a rough diſcource to drawe on a ſmooth excuſe reſembling Lapidaries, who thinke to hide the crake in a ſtone by ſetting it deepe in golde. The Gods ſupped once with poore Baucis, the Perſian kings ſometimes ſhaued ſtickes, our hope is, your heighneſſe wil at this time lend an eare to an idle paſtime. Appion raiſing Homere from hell, demanded onely who was his father, and we calling Alexander from his graue, ſeeke onely who was his loue. Whatſoeuer we preſent, we wiſh it may be thought the daunſing of Agrippa his ſhadowes: who, in the moment they were ſeene, were of any ſhape one woulde conceiue: or Lynces, who hauing a quicke ſight to diſcerne, haue a ſhort memorie to forget. With vs it is like to fare, as with theſe torches, which giuing light to others, conſume themſelues, and wee ſhewing delight to others, ſhame our ſelues.

div.head: The Prologue at the Black fryers.
div.p:
THey that feare the ſtinging of waſpes make fannes of peacockes tailes, whoſe ſpots are like eies. And Lepidus, which coulde not ſleepe for the chatting of birdes, ſet vp a beaſte, whoſe head was like a dragon: and we which ſtande in awe of reporte, are compelled to ſette beefore our owle Pallas ſhield thinking by her vertue to couer the others deformitie. It was a ſigne of famine to Aegypte, when Nilus flowed leſſe then twelue Cubites, or more then eighteene: and it may threaten diſpaire vnto vs, if we be leſſe curious then you looke for, or more comberſome. But as Theſeus being promiſed to be brought to an Eagles neaſt, and trauailing al the day, found but a wrenne in a hedg, yet ſaid, this is a bird: ſo we hope if the ſhower of our ſwelling mountaine ſeeme to bring foorth ſome Eliphant, perfourme but a mouſe, you will gently ſay, this is a beaſt. Baſill ſoftly touched, yeeldeth a ſweete ſent but chafed in the hand, a ranke ſauour. Wee feare euen ſo that our labours ſlylye glaunced on, will breede ſome content, but examined to the proofe, ſmall commendation. The haſte in performing ſhall bee our excuſe. There went two nightes to the begetting of Hercules. Feathers appeare not on the Phoenix vnder ſeauen monethes, and the mulbery is twelue in budding, but our trauailes are like the Hares, who at one time bringeth foorth, nouriſheth, and engendreth againe, or like the broode of Trochilus, whoſe egges in the ſame moment
that they are layd, become birdes. But howſoeuer we finiſh our worke, we craue pardō, if we offend in matter, and patience if we tranſgreſſe in manners. We haue mixed mirth with counſell, and diſcipline with delight, thinking it not amiſſe, in the ſame garden to ſowe pothearbes, that we ſet flowers. But we hope, as Harts that caſt their hornes, Snakes their skinnes, Eagles their bils, become more freſh for any other labour: ſo our charge being ſhaken of, we ſhalbe fitte for greater matters. But leaſt like the Mindyans, we make our gates greater then our towne, and that our play runnes out at the preface, we here conclude: wiſhing that although there bee in your preciſe iudgementes an vniuerſall miſlike, yet wee maye enioy by your woonted courtiſies a general ſilēce

div.head: Actus primus. Schaena prima.
div.stage: Clytus, Permenio, Timoclea, Campaſpe, Alexander, Hepheſtion.

sp.speaker: Clyt.
sp.p: PArmenio I cannot tel whether I ſhould more commend in Alexanders victories, courage, or curteſie, in the one being a reſolution without feare in the other a liberality aboue cuſtome: Thebes is rayſed, the people not racked, towers throwne down, bodies not thruſt aſide, a conqueſt without conflict, and a cruell warre in a milde peace.

sp.speaker: Parmenio.
sp.p: Clytus, it becommeth the ſonne of Phillip to be none other then Alexander is: therfore ſeeing in the father a ful perfection, who could haue doubted in the ſon an excellencie. For as the moone can borrow nothing els of the ſunne but light, ſo of a ſire, in whome nothing but vertue was, what coulde the childe receiue but ſingular? it is for Turkies to ſtaine each other, not for Diamondes, in the one to bee made a difference in goodnes, in the other no compariſion.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p: You miſtake mee Parmenio, if whileſt I commend Alexander, you imagine I call Phillip into queſtion, vnleſſe happely you coniecture (which none of iudgment will conceiue) that becauſe I like the fruit, therefore I heaue at the tree, or coueting to kiſſe the child, I therfore go about to poyſon the teat.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: I but Clytus, I perceiue you are borne in the Eaſt, and neuer laugh but at the ſunne riſing, which argueth though a duetie where you ought, yet no great deuotion where you might.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p:
We will make no controuerſie of that which there ought to be no queſtion, onely this ſhal be the opinion
of vs both, that none was worthy to be the father of Alexander but Phillip, nor any meete to bee the ſonne of Phillip but Alexander.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Soft Clytus, behold the ſpoiles & priſoners, a pleaſaunt ſight to vs, becauſe profit is ioyned with honour, not much paineful to them, becauſe their captiuitie is eaſed by mercy.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Fortune, thou didſt neuer yet deceiue vertue, becauſe vertue neuer yet did truſt fortune. Sworde and fire will neuer get ſpoyle, where wiſdome and fortitude beares ſway. O Thebes, thy walles were rayſed by the ſweetneſſe of the harpe, but raced by the ſhrilnes of the trumpet. Alexander had neuer come ſo neere the wals. had Epaminondas walkt about the walles, and yet might the Thebanes haue beene mery in there ſtreetes, if he had beene to watch their to wers. But deſtinie is ſeldome foreſeene, neuer preuented. We are here now captiues, whoſe neckes are yoaked by force, but whoſe harts can not yeelde by death. Come Campaſpe and the reſt, let vs not be aſhamed to caſt our eyes one him, on whom wee feared not to caſt our dartes.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Madame, you neede not doubt, it is Alexander, that is, the conquerour.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Alex. hath ouercome, not conquered.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: To bring al vnder his ſubiection is to cōquer.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: He cannot ſubdue that which is diuine.

sp.speaker: Parme
sp.p: Thebes was not.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Vertue is.

sp.speaker: Clytus.
sp.p: Alexander as he tendreth vertue, ſo he Will you, he drinketh not bloud, but thirſteth after honor, he is greedy of victory, but neuer ſatified with mercy. In fight terrible, as becometh a captaine, in conqueſte milde, as beſeemeth a king. In al things, then which nothing can be greater, he is Alexander.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p:
Then if it be ſuch a thing to be Alexander, I hope it ſhalbe no miſerable things to be a virgin. For if
he ſaue our honors, it is more thē to reſtore our goods. And rather doe I wiſh hee preſerue our fame, then our lyues, which if he do, wee will confeſſe there can be no greater thing then to be Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Clitus, are theſe priſoners? of whēce theſe ſpoiles?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Like your maieſty, they are priſoners, & of Thebes.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Of what calling or reputation?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I know not, but they ſeeme to be Ladies of honor.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I wil know. Madam, of whence you are I know: but who I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Alexander, I am the ſiſter of Theagenes, who fought a battle with thy father before the City of Chyronie, where he died, I ſay which nōe cā gainſay, valiātly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Lady, there ſeeme in your words ſparkes of your brothers deedes, but woorſer fortune in your life then his death: but feare not, for you ſhall liue without violence, enemies, or necesſitie, but what are you fayre Lady, another ſiſter to Theagines?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: No ſiſter to Theagines, but an humble handmaid to Alexander, borne of a meane parentage, but to extreame fortune.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well Ladies, for ſo your vertues ſhew you, whatſoeuer your birthes be, you ſhal be honourably entreated. Athens ſhalbe your Thebes, & you ſhal not be as abiectes of warre, but as ſubiectes to Alexander Permenio, conducte theſe honourable Ladies into the Citie: charge the ſouldiers not ſo much as in wordes to offer them any offence, and let all wants be ſupplyed, ſo farre forth as ſhalbe neceſſary for ſuch perſons & my priſoners.

div.p: Hepheſtion, it reſteth now that we haue as great care to gouerne in peace, as conquer in war: that whileſt armes ceaſe, artes may flouriſh, and ioyning letters with launces, we endeuor to be as good Philoſophers as ſoldiers, knowing it no leſſe praiſe to be wiſe, thē commendable to be vailiant.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: Your Maieſtie therin ſheweth that you haue as great deſire to rule as to ſubdue, & needes muſt that common wealth be fortunate, whoſe captaine is a Philoſopher, and whoſe Philoſopher is a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: I ſerue in ſteede of a maiſter, a mouſe, whoſe houſe is a tub, whoſe dinner is a cruſt, and whoſe boord is a bed.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p: Then art thou in a ſtate of life, which Philoſophers commend. A crumme for thy ſupper, an hande for thy cup, and thy clothes for thy ſheetes. I or Natura paucis contenta.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Manes, it is pittie ſo proper a man ſhould be caſt away vppon a Philoſopher: but that Diogenes that dogge ſhould haue Manes, that dogbolt, it greeneth nature and ſpiteth arte, the one hauing found thee ſo diſſolute, abſolute I would ſay, in body, the other ſo ſingle ſingular in minde.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Are you mery, it is a ſigne by the trip of your tongue, and the toyes of your head, that you haue done that to day, which I haue not done theſe three dayes.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: Dined.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: I thinke Diogenes keepes but cold cheere.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I would it were ſo, but hee keepeth neither hot nor cold.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What then, lucke warme? That made Manes runne from his maiſter laſt day.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p: Manes had reaſon: for his name foretold as much.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: My name? how ſo ſir boy?

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: You know that it is called Mons, à mouendo, becauſe it ſtandes ſtill.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: And thou art named Manes, à manendo, beecauſe thou runſt away.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Pasſing reaſons, I did not runne awaye, but retire.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: To a priſon, becauſe thou woldeſt haue leiſure to contemplate.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: I will proue that my body was immortall: beecauſe it was in priſon.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: Didde your maiſters neuer teach you that the ſoule is immortall?

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: And the body is the priſon of the ſoule.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: Why then, thus to make my body immortal, I put it to priſon.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Oh bad.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p: Excellent ill.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: You may ſee how dull a faſting wit is: therfore Pſyllus let vs go to ſupper with Granichus: Plato is the beſt fellow of al Phyloſophers. Giue me him that reades in the morning in the ſchoole, and at noone in the kitchin.

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: And me.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Ah ſirs, my maiſter is a king in his parlour for the body, and a God in his ſtudy for the ſoule. Among all his menne he commedeth one that is an excellent Muſition, then ſtand I by, & clap another on the ſhoulder, and ſay, this is a pasſing good Cooke.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: It is well doone Granichus, for giue me pleaſure that goes in at the mouth, not the eare, I had rather fill my guttes, then my braines.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p:
I ſerue Apelles, whoe feedeth mee as Diogenes
doth Manes, for at dinner the one preacheth abſtinence, the other commendeth counterfeiting: when I would eat meat, he paintes a ſpit, & whē I thirſt, O ſaith he, is not this a faire pot, and points to a table, whiche cōteines the banquet of the Gods, where are many diſhes to feede the eie, but not to fill the gut.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What dooſt thou then?

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: This doeth hee then bring in many examples that ſome haue liued by ſauours, & proueth that much eaſier it is to fatte by colours: and telles of birdes that haue beene fatted by painted grapes in winter: & how many haue ſo fed their eies with their miſtreſſe picture, that they neuer deſired to take food, being glutted with the delight in their fauours. Then doth he ſhew me coū terfeits, ſuch as haue ſurfeited with their filthy & lothſome vomits, and with the riotous Bacchanalles of the God Bacchus, & his diſorderly crew, which are painted al to the life in his ſhop. To cōclude, I fare hardly, thogh I go richly, which maketh me when I ſhuld begin to ſhadow a Ladies face, to draw a Lambes head, & ſometime to ſet to the body of a maide a ſhoulder of mutton: for ſemper animus meus eſt in patinis.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Thou art a God to me: for could I ſee but a Cookes ſhop painted, I would make mine eyes fatte as butter. For I haue nought but ſentences to fil my maw, as plures occidit crapula quàm gladius, muſa ieiunantibus amica: repletion killeth delicately: & an old ſaw of abſtinence, Socrates, The belly is the heads greue. Thus with ſayings not with meate he maketh a gally mafrey.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: But how doeſt thou then liue?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: With fine ieſts, ſweet aire, & the dogs almes.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Wel for this time I wil ſtanch thy gut, & amōg pots & platters thou ſhalt ſee what it is to ſerue Plato.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p: For ioy of Granichus lets ſing.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: My voice is as cleare in the euening as in the morning.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Another commodity of emptines.

div.head: Actus primus, Schaena tertia,
div.stage: Melipus, Plato, Ariſtotle, Criſippus, Crates, Cleanthes. Anaxarchus, Alexander, Hepheſtion, Parmenio, Clytus, Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Melip,
sp.p: I had neuer ſuch a doe to warne ſchollers to come before a king. Firſt, I cam to Criſippus a tall leane old mad man, willing him preſently to appeare before Alexander, he ſtoode ſtaring on my face, neither mouing his eies nor his body, I vrging him to giue ſome anſwer, hee tooke vp a booke, ſate downe, and ſaide nothing: Meliſſa his maid told me it was his manner, and that oftētimes ſhe was fain to thruſt meate into his mouth: for that he wold rather ſtarue thē ceaſſe ſtudie. Well thoght I, ſeeing bookiſh men are ſo blockiſh, & ſo great clarkes ſuch ſimple courtiers, I wil neither be partaker of their cōmons nor their commēdations. Frō thence I came to Plato & to Ariſtotle, and to diuerſe other, none refuſing to come, ſauing an old obſcure fellowe, who ſitting in a tub turned towardes the ſunne, reade Greek to a yong boy, him when I willed to appeare before Alexander, he anſweared, if Alexander wold faine ſee me, let him come to mee, if learne of me, lette him come to me, whaſoeuer it be, let him come to me. why, ſaid I, he is a king, he anſwered, why I am a Philoſopher, why, but he is Alexander: I but I am Diogenes. I was halfe angry to ſee one ſo crooked in his ſhape, to be ſo crabbed in his ſayings. So going my way, I ſaid thou ſhalt repent it, if thou cōmeſt not to Alexander: nay ſmiling anſwered he: Alexander may repent it, if he come not to Diogenes, vertue muſt be ſought, not offered: and ſo turning himſelf to his cel, he grunted I know not what, like a pig vnder a tub. But I muſt be gone, the Philoſophers are comming. Exit.

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: It is a difficult controuerſie, Aristotle, and rather to be wondred at, then beleeued, how natural cauſes ſhould worke ſupernatural effects.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: I doe not ſo much ſtand vpon the apparition is ſeene in the Moone, neither the Demonium of Socrates, as that I cannot by naturall reaſon giue any reaſon of the ebbing and flowing of the Sea, which makes me in the depth of my ſtudies to crye out, O ens entium, miſerere mei.

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: Cleanthes and you attribute ſo muche to nature by ſearching for things which are not to be found, that whileſt you ſtudie a cauſe of your owne, you omitte the occaſion it ſelfe. There is no man ſo ſauage in whom reſteth not this diuine particle, that there is an omnipotent, eternal and deuine mouer, which may be called God.

sp.speaker: Cleant.
sp.p: I am of this minde, that that firſt mouer, which you tearme God, is the inſtrument of all the mouings, which we attribute to nature. The earth which is maſſe, ſwimmeth on the ſea, ſeaſons deuided in themſelues, fruits growing in themſelues, the maieſtie of the skie, the whole firmament of the world, & whatſoeuer els appeareth miraculous, what man almoſt of meane capacity but can proue it naturall.

sp.speaker: Anaxar.
sp.p: Theſe cauſes ſhalbe debated at our Philoſophers feaſt, in which controuerſie I wil take parte with Ariſtotle, that there is Natura naturans, & yet not God.

sp.speaker: Craterus.
sp.p: And I with Plato, that there is Deus optimus maximus, and not nature.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: Here commeth Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I ſee Hepheſtion, that theſe Philoſophers are here attending for vs.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: They were not Philoſophers, if they knew not their dueties.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But I much maruaile Diogenes ſhoulde be ſo dogged.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: I doe not think but his excuſe wilbe better then Melippus meſſage.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I will go ſee him Hepheſtion, becauſe I long to ſee him that would commaund Alexander to come, to whom al the world is like to come. Ariſtotle & the reſt ſithence my comming from Thebes to Athens, from a place of conqueſt to a pallace of quiet, I haue reſolued with my ſelf in my court to haue as many Philiſophers, as I had in my camp ſoldiers. My court ſhalbe a ſchole, wherein I wil haue vſed as great doctrine in peace, as I did in warre diſcipline.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: We are al here ready to be commaunded, & glad we are that we are commaunded: for that nothing better becommeth kings thē literature, which maketh them come as neere to the Gods in wiſdome, as they do in dignitie.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It is ſo Ariſtotle: but yet there is among you, yea & of your bringing vp, that ſought to deſtroy Alexander: Caliſtenes, Ariſtotle, whoſe treaſons againſte his prince ſhall not bee borne out with the reaſons of his Phyloſophy.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: If euer miſchiefe entred into the heart of Caliſtenes, let Caliſtenes ſuffer for it, but that Ariſtotle euer imagined any ſuch thing of Caliſtenes, Ariſtotle doth denie.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well Ariſtotle, kindred may blind thee, and affection mee, but in kinges cauſes I will not ſtande to ſchollers arguments. This meeting ſhalbe for a cōmandement, that you all frequent my courte inſtructe the young with rules confirme the olde with reaſons: lette your liues be anſwerable to your learnings, leaſte my proceedings by contrary to my promiſes.

sp.speaker: Hepheſt.
sp.p: You ſayde you woulde aske euery one of them a queſtion, which yeſter night none of vs coulde aunſwere.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I will Plato, of all beaſtes, which is the ſubtilleſt?

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: That which man hetherto neuer knew.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ariſtotle, how ſhould a man be thought a God?

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: In doing a thing vnposſible for a man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Criſippus, which was firſt, the day or the night?

sp.speaker: Criſp.
sp.p: The day by a day.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Indeede ſtraunge queſtions muſt haue ſtraung anſweres. Cleanthes, what ſay you, is life or death the ſtronger?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Life, that ſuffereth ſo many troubles.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Crates, how long ſhould a man liue?

sp.speaker: Crates.
sp.p: Till he thinke it better to die then liue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Anaxarchus, whether doth the ſea or the earth bring forth moſt creatures?

sp.speaker: Anax.
sp.p: The earth, for the ſea is but a parte of the earth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hepheſtion, me thinkes they haue aunſwered all well, & in ſuch queſtions I meane often to trie them.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: It is better to haue in your courte a wiſe man then in your ground a golden mine. Therefore would I leaue war, to ſtudie wiſdom, were I Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: So would I, were I Hepheſtion. But come, let vs go and giue releaſe, as I promiſed, to our Thebā thralles.

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: Thou art fortunate Ariſtotle, that Alexander is thy ſcholler.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: And you happy that he is your ſoueraigne.

sp.speaker: Criſip.
sp.p: I could like the man well, if he could be contē ted to be but a man.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: He ſeeketh to draw neere to the Gods in knowledge, not to be a God.

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: Let vs queſtiō a litle with Diogenes, why he went not with vs to Alexander. Diogenes, thou didſt forget thy dutie, that thou wentſt not with vs to the king.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And you your profeſsion, that you went to the king.

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: Thou takeſt as great pride to bee peeuiſh, as others doe glory to bee vertuous.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And thou as great honor being a Philoſopher to bee thought courtlike, as others ſhame that be courtiers, to be accounted Philoſophers.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: Theſe auſtere maners ſet a ſide, it is wel known that thou didſt counterfeate monye.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And thou thy maners, in that thou didſte not counterfeite money.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: Thou haſt reaſon to cōtemn the courte, being both in body and mynde too crooked for a courtier.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: As good be crooked, and endeuour to make my ſelf ſtraight from the court, as to be ſtraight and learne to be crooked at the court.

sp.speaker: Crates
sp.p: Thou thinkeſt it a grace to be oppoſite againſt Alexander.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And thou to be iump with Alexander.

sp.speaker: Anax.
sp.p: Let vs go: for in contemning him, wee ſhall better pleaſe him, than in wondring at him.

sp.speaker: Ariſt.
sp.p: Plato, what doſt thou thinke of Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: To be Socrates furious, let vs go.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Behold Manes where thy maiſter is, ſeeking either for bones for his dinner, or pinnes for his ſleeues. I wil go ſalute him.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Doe ſo: but mum, not a woord you ſawe Manes.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: Then ſtay thou behinde, I will goe with Pſyllus.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: All haile Diogenes to your proper perſon.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: All hate to thy peeuiſh conditions.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: O Dogge.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: What doſt thou ſeeke for here?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: For a man and a beaſt.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: That is eaſie without thy light to be found, bee not all theſe men?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Called men.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What beaſt is it thou lookeſt for?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: The beaſt my man Manes.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: He is a beaſt indeede that will ſerue thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: So is he that begat thee.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What wouldeſt thou do, if thou ſhouldeſt find Manes?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Giue him leaue to doo as he hath done before.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Whats that.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: To runne away.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Why, haſt thou no neede of Manes?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: It were a ſhame for Diogenes to haue neede of Manes, & for Manes to haue no need of Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: But put the caſe he were gone, wouldeſt thou entertaine any of vs two?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Vpon condition.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: That you ſhould tell me wherefore any of you both were good.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Why, I am a ſcholler, and well ſeene in Phyloſophy.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: And I a prentice, and well ſeene in painting.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Well then Granichus, bee thou a painter to amend thine yll face, & thou Pſyllus a Phyloſopher, to correct thine euil manners. But who is that, Manes?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I care not who I were, ſo I were not Manes.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: You are taken tardie.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Let vs ſlip aſide Granichus, to ſee the ſalutation betweene Manes and his maiſter.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Manes, thou knoweſt the laſt day I threw away my diſh, to drink in my hād, becauſe it was ſuperfluous, now I am determined to put away my man, and ſerue my ſelfe: Quia non egeo tui vel te.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: Maiſter, you know a while a goe I ran awaye, ſo doe I meane to do againe, quia ſcio tibi non eſſe argentum.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I know I haue no mony, neither will I haue euer a man, for I was reſolued longe ſithence to put away both my ſlaues, money and Manes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: So was I determined to ſhake of both my dogs, hunger and Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: O ſweete conſent beetweene a crowde and a Iewes harp.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Come, let vs reconcile them.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: It ſhall not neede: for this is their vſe, nowe do they dine one vpon another.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: How now Manes, art thou gone from thy maiſter.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Noe, I didde but nowe bynde my ſelfe to him.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Why, you were at mortall iars.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: In faith no, wee brake a bitter ieſt one vppon another.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Why, thou art as dogged as he.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: My father knew them both litle whelpes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Well, I will hie mee after my maiſter.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Why, is it ſupper time with Diogenes?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I, with him at al times when he hath meate.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Why then, euery man to his home, and lette vs ſteale out againe anone.

sp.speaker: Grani
sp.p: Where ſhall we meete.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Why, at Ala vendibili ſuſpenſa haedera non eſt opus.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: O Pſyllus, habeo te loco parentis, thou bleſſeſt me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Stand aſide ſir boy, till you be called. Hepheſtion, how doe yee like the ſweete face of Campaſpe.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: I cannot but commend the ſtoute courage of Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Without doubt Campaſpe had ſome great man to her father.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: You know Timoclea had Theagines to her brother,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Timoclea ſtil in thy mouth, art thou not in loue?

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Not with Timoclea you meane, wherein you reſemble the Lapwing, who crieth moſt, where her neaſt is not. And ſo you lead me from eſpying your loue with Campaſpe, you cry Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: Could I aſwell ſubdue kingdomes, as I can my thoughtes, or were I as farre from ambition, as I am frō loue, al the world wold account me as valiant in armes, as I know my ſelf moderate in affection.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Is loue a vice?

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: It is no vertue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Well, now ſhalt thou ſee what ſmall difference I make betweene Alexander and Hepheſtion. And ſith thou haſte beene alwayes partaker of my triumphes, thou ſhalt be partaker of my tormētes. I loue Hepheſtion, I loue I loue Campaſpe, a thing farre Vnfit for a Macedonian, for a king, for Alexander. Why hangeſt thou down thy head Hepheſtion? bluſhing to heare that which
I am not aſhamed to tell.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Might my wordes craue pardon, and my counſel credite, I woulde both diſcharge the duetie of a ſubiect, for ſo I am, & the office of a friend, for ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Speake Hepheſtion for what ſoeuer is ſpoken, Hepheſtion ſpeaketh to Alexander.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p:
I can not tel, Alexander, whether the reporte be more ſhameful to be heard or the cauſe ſorowfull to be beleeued? What? is the ſonne of Phillip, king of Macedon become the ſubiect of Campaſpe the captiue of Thebes? Is that minde, whoſe greatnes the world could not containe, drawn within the compaſſe of an idle alluring eie? Wil you handle the ſpindle with Hercules, when you ſhould ſhake the ſpeare with Achilles? Is the warlike ſoūd of drumme, and trumpe turned to the ſoft noyſe of lire, and lute, the neighing of barbed ſteeds, whoſe loudnes filled the ayre with terrour, and whoſe breathes dimmed the ſunne with ſmoak, conuerted to dilicate tunes and amorous glaunces? O Alexander, that ſoft and yeelding minde ſhould not bee in him, whoſe hard and vnconquered heart hath made ſo many yeelde. But you loue, ah griefe, but whom? Campaſpe, ah ſhame, a maide forſooth vnknowne, vnnoble, & who can tell whether immodeſt? whoſe eies are framed by nature to inamour, & whoſe heart was made by nature to inchaunt. I, but ſhe is bewtiful, yea but not therefore chaſt: I, but ſhe is comly in al parts of the body: yea, but ſhe may be crooked in ſome part of the mind: I, but ſhe is wiſe, yea, but ſhe is a woman? Bewty is like the black berry which ſeemeth red, when it is not ripe, reſembling pretious ſtoēs that are poliſhed with honny, which the ſmother they look, the ſooner they breake. It is thought wonderful among the ſea men, that Mugil of all fiſhes, the ſwifteſt, is found in the belly of the Bret of al the ſloweſt: And ſhall it not ſeeme monſtrous to wiſemen, that the hearte of the greateſt conquerour of the worlde, ſhould be found
in the handes of the weakeſt creature of nature? of a woman? of a captiue? Hermyns haue faire skinnes, but fowle liuers, Sepulchres freſh colours, but rottē bones, women faire faces, but falſe heartes. Remember Alexander thou haſt a campe to gouerne, not a chamber, fall not from the armour of Mars to the armes of Venus, from the fiery aſſaults of war, to the maidēly skirmiſhes of loue, from diſplaying the Eagle in thine enſigne, to ſet downe the ſparow. I ſighe Alexander that where fortune could not conquer, folly ſhuld ouercome. But behold al the perfection that may be in Campaſpe, a hayre curling by nature not arte: ſweete alluring eies, a faire face made in diſpite of Venus, and a ſtately porte in diſdaine of Iuno, a witte apt to conceiue, and quick to anſwere a skin as ſoft as ſilk, and as ſmooth as iet, a longe white hand, a fine litle foote, to conclude, all partes anſwerable to the beſt part, what of this? Though ſhe haue heauenly giftes, vertue and bewtie, is ſhe not of earthly mettal fleſh and bloud? You Alexander that would be a God, ſhew your ſelfe in this worſe then a man, ſo ſoone to be both ouerſeene and ouertaken in a womā, whoſe falſe teares know their true times, whoſe ſmooth words wound deeper then ſharpe ſwordes. There is no ſurfeit ſo dangerous, as that of honney, nor anye poyſon ſo deadly, as that of loue, in the one phiſicke cannot preuaile, nor in the other counſell.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
My caſe were light Hepheſtion, and not worthy to be called loue, if reaſon were a remedy, or ſentences could ſalue, that ſence cānot conceiue. Litle do you know, and therefore ſleightly do you regarde the dead embers in a priuate perſō, or liue coles in a great prince, whoſe pasſions and thoughts do as far exceede others in extremitie, as their callings doe in Maieſtie. An Eclipſe in the Sunne is more then the falling of a ſtarre, none can conceiue the torments of a king, vnleſſe hee be a king whoſe deſires are not inferior to their dignities.
And then iudge Hepheſtion if the agonies of loue be dangerous in a ſubiect, whether they be not more then deadly vnto Alexander, whoſe deep and not to be conceiued ſighes, cleaue the hart in ſhiuers: whoſe woū ded thoughtes can neither be expreſſed nor endured. Ceaſe then Hephestion, with arguments to ſeeke to refel that, which with their deitie the Gods cannot reſiſt, & let this ſuffice to aunſwere thee that it is a king that loueth and Alexander, whoſe affectiōs are not to be meaſured by reaſon, being immortall, nor I feare me to be borne being intollerable.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: I muſt needs yeeld, when neither reaſon nor counſell can be heard.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yeeld Hepheſtion, for Alexander doth loue, and therefore muſt obtaine.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: Suppoſe ſhe loues not you, affection commeth not by appointmente or birth, & then as good hated as enforced.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I am a king, and will commaund.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: You may to yeelde to luſte by force, but to conſent to loue by feare you cannot.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, what is that, which Alexander may not conquer as he liſt?

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: Why, that which you ſay the Gods cannot reſiſte, Loue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I am a conquerour, ſhe a captiue, I as fortunate, as ſhe faire: my greatnes may aunſwere her wants, and the giftes of my minde, the modeſtie of hers: Is it not likely then that ſhe ſhould loue? Is it not reaſonable?

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: You ſay that in loue there is no reaſon, & therfore there can be no likelyhood.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
No more Hepheſtion, in this caſe I wil vſe mine owne counſell, and in all other thine aduice, thou maiſt be a good ſoldier, but neuer good louer. Cal my Page. Sirha, goe preſently to Apelles, and will him to come to
me without either delay or excuſe.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I goe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: In the meane ſeaſon to recreate my ſpirits, being ſo neare, we will goe ſee Diogenes, and ſee where his tub is. Diogenes?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Who calleth?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Alexander. How happened it that you woulde not come out of your tub to my palace?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Becauſe it was as far from my tub to your pallace, as from your palace to my tub.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why thē doeſt thou ow no reuerēce to kings:

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Becauſe they be no Gods.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: They be Gods of the earth.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Yea, Gods of earth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Plato is not of thy mind.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Becauſe I would haue none of Diogenes minde but Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: If Alexander haue any thing that may pleaſure Diogenes, let me know, and take it.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Then take not from me, that you cannot giue me, the light of the world.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What doeſt thou want?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Nothing that you haue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I haue the world at commaund.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And I in contempt.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt liue no longer than I will.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But I will die whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: How ſhould one learn to be content?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Vnlearn to couet.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hepheſtion, were I not Alexander, I wolde wiſhe to be Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p:
He is dogged, but diſcrete, I cannot tel how
ſharpe with a kinde of ſweetenes, ful of wit, yet too too wayward.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Diogenes, whē I come this way again, I will both ſee thee, and confer with thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Doe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But here commeth Apelles, how now Apelles, is Venus face yet finiſhed

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Not yet: Bewty is not ſo ſoone ſhadowed whoſe perfection commeth not within the compaſſe either of cunning or of colour.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well let it reſt vnperfect, & come you with me, where I wil ſhewe you that finiſhed by nature, that you haue beene trifling about by art.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Lady, I doubt whether there bee any colour ſo freſh, that may ſhadow a countenance ſo faire.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Sir, I had thought you had beene commaunded to paint with your hand, not to gloſe with your tongue, but as I haue heard, it is the hardeſt thing in painting to ſet down a hard fauour, which maketh you to diſpair of my face, and then ſhall you haue as great thanks to ſpare your labour, as to diſcredit your arte.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Miſtreſſe, you neither differ from you ſelfe, nor your ſex: for knowing your owne perfection, you ſeeme to diſpraiſe that which men moſt cōmend, drawing thē by that meane into an admiration, where feeding them ſelues they fall into an extaſie, your modeſtie being the cauſe of the one, and of the other, your affections.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I am too young to vnderſtande your ſpeache, thogh old enough to withſtand your deuiſe: you haue bin ſo long vſed to colours, you cā do nothing but colour.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p:
Indeed the colours I ſee, I feare wil alter the colour I haue: but come madam, will you draw neere, for
Alexander will be here anon. Pſyllus, ſtay you heere at the window, if anye enquire for me, aunſwere, Non lubet eſſe domi.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: It is alwayes my maiſters faſhion, when any fair Gentlewoman is to be drawne within, to make mee to ſtay without. But if he ſhuld paint Iupiter like a Bul, like a Swan, like an Eagle, then muſt Pſyllus with one hand grind colours, and with the other hold the candle. But let him alone, the better he ſhadowes her face, the more will he burne his owne heart. And now if a manne cold meet with Manes, who I dare ſay, lookes as leane, as if Diogenes dropped out of his noſe.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: And here comes Manes, whoe hath as muche meate in his maw, as thou haſt honeſtie in thy head.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Then I hope thou art very hungry.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: They that know thee, know that.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: But doeſt thou not remember that wee haue certaine licour to conferre withall.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I, but I haue buſines, I muſt go cry a thing.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Why, what haſt thou loſt?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: That which I neuer had my dinner.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Foule lubber wilt thou crye for thy dinner?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I meane, I muſt cry, not as one would ſaye cry, but cry, that is make a noyſe.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Why foole, that is al one, for if thou cry, thou muſt needes make a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Boy thou art deceiued. Cry hath diuerſe ſignifications, and may bee alluded to manye things, knaue but one, and can be applyed but to thee.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Profound Manes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p:
Wee Cynickes are madde fellowes, didſte thou
not finde I did quip thee?

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: No verely, why, what is a quip.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: We great girders cal it a ſhort ſaying of a ſharp witte, with a bitter ſenſe in a ſweete word.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: How canſt thou thus diuine, deuide, define, diſpute, and all on the ſuddaine?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Wit wil haue his ſwing, I am bewitcht, inſpird, inflamed, infected.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Well, then will not I tempt thy gybing ſpirite.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Do not Pſyllus, for thy dull head will bee but a grindſtone for my quick wit, which if thou whet with ouerwhartes, periſti, actum eſt de te. I haue drawne bloud at ones braines with a bitter bob.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Let me croſſe my ſelfe: for I die, if I croſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Let me do my buſines, I my ſelf am afraid, leaſt my wit ſhould waxe warm, and then muſt it needs conſume ſome hard head with fine & prety ieſts. I am ſome times in ſuch a vaine, that for want of ſome dull pate to worke on, I begin to gird my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: The Gods ſhield mee from ſuch a fine fellowe, whoſe words melt wits like waxe.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Well then, let vs to the matter. In fayth my maiſter meaneth to morrow to fly.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: It is a ieſt.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Is it a ieſt to flye: ſhouldeſt thou flye ſo ſoone, thou ſhouldeſt repent it in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Well, I will be the cryer.

sp.speaker: Manes and Pſyl. one after an other.
sp.p: O ys, o ys, o ys, Al manner of men, women or children, that will come to morow into the market place, between the houres of nine and ten, ſhall ſee Diogenes the Cynick flye.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: I do not think he will flye.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Tuſh, ſay fly.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Fly.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Now let vs goe: for I will not ſee him againe til midnight, I haue a back way into his tub.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Which way calleſt thou the backwaye, when euery way is open.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I meane to come in at his back.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Well, let vs goe away, that wee may returne ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I ſhall neuer drawe your eies well, becauſe they blind mine.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Why thē, paint me without eies, for I am blind.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Were you euer ſhadowed before of any?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: No. And would you could ſo now ſhadow me, that I might not be perceiued of any?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: It were pittie, but that ſo abſolute a face ſhould furniſh Venus temple amongſt theſe pictures.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What are theſe pictures?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Laeda, whom loue deceiued in likenes of a ſwan.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: A faire woman, but a foule deceit.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Alcmena, Vnto whō Iupiter came in ſhape of Amphitriō her husband, and begat Hercules.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: A famous ſonne, but an infamous fact.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: He might do it, becauſe he was a God.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Nay, therefore it was euill done, becauſe he was a God.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Danae, into whoſe priſon Iupiter driſled a golden ſhewre, and obtained his deſire?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What Gold can make one yeelde to deſire?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Europa, whom Iupiter rauiſhed: this Antiopa.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Were al the Gods like this Iupiter?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: There were many Gods in this like Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p:
I thinke in thoſe dayes loue was wel ratified among
men on earth, when luſt was ſo ful authoriſed by the Gods in heauen.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Nay, you may imagine there wer womē pasſing amiable, when there were Gods exceeding amorous.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Were women neuer ſo faire, mē wold be falſe.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Were womē neuer ſo falſe, men wold be fond.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What counterfeit is this Appelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Venus, the Goddeſſe of loue.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What, be there alſo louing Goddeſſes?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is ſhe that hath power to commaunde the very affections of the heart.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: How is ſhe hired: by praier, by ſacrifice, or bribs?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: By praier, ſacrifice and bribes.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What praier?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Vowes irreuocable.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What ſacrifice?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Heartes euer ſighing neuer diſſembling.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What bribes.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Roſes and kiſſes: but were you neuer in loue?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: No, nor loue in me.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Then haue you iniuried many.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Becauſe you haue beene loued of many.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Flattered parchance of ſome.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: It is not posſible that a face ſo faire, & a wit ſo ſharpe, both without compariſon, ſhuld not be apt to loue.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: If you begin to tip your tongue with cunning, I pray you dip your penſil in colours, and fall to that you muſt doe, not that you would doe.

div.head: Actus tertius, Schaena quarta.
div.stage: Clytus, Parmenio, Alexander, Hepheſtion, Criſus, Diogenes, Apelles, Campaſpe.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p:
Parmenio, I cannot tel how it commeth to paſſe, that in Alexander now a daies there groweth an vnpatiēt kinde of life, in the morning he is melancholy, at noone
ſolomne, at all times either more ſower or ſeuere, then he was accuſtomed.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: In kinges cauſes I rather loue to doubt then coniecture, and think it better to be ignoraunt then inquiſitiue: they haue long eares and ſtretched armes, in whoſe heades ſuſpition is a proofe, and to be accuſed is to be condemned.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p: Yet betweene vs there canne be no danger to finde out the cauſe: for that there is no malice to withſtand it. It may be an vnquenchable thirſte of conquering maketh him vnquiet: it is not vnlikly his long eaſe hath altred his humour: that he ſhould bee in loue, it is not imposſible.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: In loue Clytus? no, no, it is as farre from his thought, as treaſon in ours, he whoſe euer waking eye, whoſe neuer tried heart, whoſe body patient of labour, whoſe mind vnſatiable of victory, hath alwayes bin noted, cannot ſo ſoone be melted into the weak conceites of loue. Ariſtotle told him there were many worlds, & that he hath not conquered one that gapeth for al, galleth Alexander. But here he commeth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Parmenio, and Clitus, I would haue you both redy to go into Perſia about an ambaſſage no leſſe profitable to me, then to your ſelues honourable.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p: We are ready at all commaundes, wiſhing nothing els, but continually to be commaunded.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well, then withdraw your ſelues, till I haue further conſidered of this matter.

div.p: Now we wil ſee how Apelles goeth forward: I doubt me that nature hath ouercom arte, & her countenance his cunning.

sp.speaker: Hepheſt.
sp.p: You loue, and therefore think any thing.

sp.speaker: Alex
sp.p: But not ſo far in loue with Campaſpe, as with Bucephalus, if occaſion ſerue either of cōflicte or of conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Hepheſt.
sp.p: Ocaſion cannot want, if wil doe not. Behold all Perſia ſwelling in the pride of their owne power. the Scithians careleſſe what courage or fortune canne doe: the Aegiptians dreaming in the ſouthſayings of their Auguries, and gaping ouer the ſmoak of their beaſts intralles. All theſe Alexander, are to bee ſubdued, if that world be not ſlipped out of your head, which you haue ſworne to conquere with that hand.

sp.speaker: Alex
sp.p: I confeſſe the labours fit for Alexander, and yet recreation neceſſary among ſo many aſſaults, bloudye wounds, intollerable troubles: giue mee leaue a litle, if not to ſitte, yet to breath. And doubt not but Alexander can, when he wil, throw affections as farre from him, as he can cowardiſe. But behold Diogenes talking with one at his tub.

sp.speaker: Cryſus
sp.p: One penny Diogenes, I am a Cynick.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: He made thee a begger, that firſt gaue thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Cryſus
sp.p: Why, if thou wilt giue nothing, no body will giue thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I want nothing, till the ſprings dry, & the earth periſh.

sp.speaker: Cryſus
sp.p: I gather for the Gods.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And I care not for thoſe gods, which want money.

sp.speaker: Cryſus
sp.p: Thou art a right Cynicke, that will giue nothing.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Thou art not, that will beg any thing.

sp.speaker: Cryſus
sp.p: Alexander, king Alexāder, giue a poore Cynick a groat.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It is not for a king to giue a groat.

sp.speaker: Cryſus
sp.p: Then giue me a talent.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It is not for a begger to aske a talent, A waye. Apelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Now Gentlewomanne, doeth not your beauty
put the painter to his trump?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Yes my Lorde, ſeeing ſo diſordered a countenaunce he feareth he ſhall ſhadow a deformed counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Wold he could colour the life with the feature. And me thinketh Apelles, were you as cūning as report ſaith you are, you may paint flowers aſwell with ſweete ſmels, as freſh colours obſeruing in your mixture ſuch things as ſhould draw neere to their ſauours.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Your maieſtie muſt know, it is no leſſe harde to paint ſauours thē vertues, colours can neither ſpeake nor think.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Where do you firſt begin, when you drawe any picture?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: The propoſition of the face in iuſt compaſſe, as I can.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I would begin with the eie, as a light to all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: If you will paint, as you are a king, your Maieſtie, may beginne where you pleaſe, but as you wold be a painter, you muſt begin with the face.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Aurelius would in one houre colour four faces.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I meruaile in half an houre he did not foure.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, is it ſo eaſie?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: No but he doth it ſo homely.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: When will you finiſh Campaſpe?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Neuer finiſhe: for alwayes in abſolute bewtie there is ſomwhat aboue arte.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why ſhould not I by labour bee as cunning as Apelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: God ſhield you ſhould haue cauſe to be ſo cunning as Apelles.

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.p: Me thinketh 4. colours are ſufficiēt to ſhadow any countenance, & ſo it was in the time of Phyaias.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p:
Thē had mē fewer fancies, & womē not ſo many fauors. For now, if the haire of her eie browes be black,
yet muſt the haire of her head be yellowe: the attire of her head muſt be different from the habit of her body, els muſt the picture ſeeme like the blaſon of auncient armorie, not like the ſweet delight of new found amiablenes. For as in garden knottes diuerſitie of odours make a more ſweet ſauor, or as in muſicke diuers ſtrings cauſe a more delicate conſent, ſo in painting, the more colours, the better counterfeit, obſeruing blacke for a ground, and the reſt for grace.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Lend me thy penſil Apelles, I will paint, & thou ſhalt iudge.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The coale breakes.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: You leane too hard.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now it blackes not.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: You leane too ſoft.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: This is awry.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Your eie goeth not with your hand.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now it is worſe.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Your hand goeth not with your mind.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Nay, if al be too hard or ſoft, ſo many rules and regardes, that ones hand, ones eie, ones minde muſt all draw together, I had rather be ſetting of a battell, then blotting of a bourd. But how haue I done heere?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Like a king.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I think ſo: but nothing more vnlike a Painter. Wel Apelles, Campaſpe is finiſhed as I wiſh, diſmiſſe her, bring preſently her counterfeit after me.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now Hepheſtion, doth not this matter cotton as I would, Campaſpe looketh pleaſauntlye, liberty wil encreaſe her bewty, & my loue ſhall aduaunce her honour.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: I wil not contrary your maieſtie, for time muſt we are out that loue hath wrought, and reaſon weane what appetite nourſed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
How ſtately ſhe paſſeth bye, yet how ſo berly, a
ſweet conſent in her countenance with a chaſt diſdaine, deſire mingled with coyneſſe, and I cannot tell how to tearme it, a curſt yeelding modeſtie.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: Let her paſſe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: So ſhe ſhall for the faireſt on the earth.

div.head: Actus tertius, Schaena quinta.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus.
sp.p: I ſhalbe hanged for tarying ſo long.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I pray God my maiſter be not flowne before I come.

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: Away Manes, my maiſter doth come.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Where haue you bin all this while?

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: No where but heere.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Who was here ſince my comming?

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: No body.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Vngratious wag, I perceiue you haue beene a loytering: was Alexander no body?

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: He was a king, I meant no meane body.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I will cogell your body for it, and then will I ſay it was no bodie, becauſe it was no honeſte body. Away in.

div.p:
Vnfortunate Apelles, and therfore vnfortunate, beecauſe Apelles. Haſt thou by drawing her bewty broght to paſſe, that thou canſt ſcarſe draw thine own breath. And by ſo much the more haſt thou encreaſed thy care, by how much the more thou haſt ſhewed thy cūning: was it not ſufficient to behold the fire and warme thee, but with Satyrus thou muſt kiſſe the fire and burne thee? O Campaſpe, Campaſpe, arte muſt yeeld to nature, reaſon to appetite, wiſdom to affection Could Pigmalion entreate
by prayer to haue his Iuory turned into fleſh? and cannot Apelles obtaine by plaints to haue the picture of his loue chaunged to life? Is painting ſo farre inferiour to caruing? or doſt thou Venus, more delight to be hewed with Chizels, then ſhadowed with colours? what Pigmalyon, or what Pyrgoteles, or what Lyſppus is hee, that euer made thy face ſo fayre or ſpread thy fame ſo farre as I? vnleſſe, Ʋenus, in this thou enuieſt mine arte, that in colouring my ſweete Campaſpe, I haue left no place by cunning to make thee ſo amiable. But alas, ſhe is the paramour to a prince. Alexander the monarch of the earth hath both her body and affection. For what is it that kinges cannot obtaine by praiers, threates and promiſes? Wil not ſhe think it better to ſit vnder a cloth of eſtate like a queene, then in a poore ſhop like a huſwife? and eſteme it ſweeter to be the concubine of the Lord of the world, then ſpouſe to a painter in Athēs? Yes, yes Apelles, thou maiſt ſwimme againſt the ſtreame with the Crab, and feede againſt the winde with the deere, and pecke againſt the ſteele with the Cockatrice: ſtarres are to be looked at, not reched at, princes to bee yeelded vnto, not contended with: Campaſpe to bee honored, not obtained to be painted not poſſeſſed of thee. O fair face, O vnhappy hand, & why didſt thou draw it ſo faire a face? O bewtifull countenance, the expreſſe image of Venus, but ſowhat freſher: the only pattern of that eternitie, which Iupiter dreaming of aſlepe, could not conceiue again wakīg Bluſh Venus, for I am aſhamed to end thee. Now muſt I paint things vnpoſſible for mine arte, but agreeable with my affections: deepe and hollowe ſighes, ſadde and melancholye thoughtes, wounds and ſlaughters of conceites, a life poſting to death, a death galloping from life, a wauering conſtancie, an vnſetled reſolution, and what not, Apelles? And what but Apelles? But as they that are ſhaken with a feuer are to bee warmed with clothes, not groanes, & as he that melteth in
a conſumption is to bee recured by Colices, not conceites: ſo the feeding cāker of my care, the neuer dying worm of my hart is to be killed by coūſel, not cries by applying of remedies, not by replying of reaſons. And ſith in caſes deſperat there muſt be vſed medicines that are extreme, I wil hazard that litle life that is left, to reſtore the greater part that is loſt, & this ſhalbe my firſt practiſe: for wit muſt work, where authoritie is not. Aſſoone as Alexander hath viewed this portraiture, I will by deuiſe giue it a blemiſh, that by that meanes ſhe may come again to my ſhop, and then as good it were to vtter my loue, and die with deniall, as conceale it, & liue in deſpaire.

div.head: Actus quartus, Schaena prima.
div.stage: Solinus, Pſyllus, Granichus, Manes, Diogenes, Populus.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.p: This is the place, the day, the time, that Diogenes hath appointed to flye.

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: I will not looſe the flight of ſo faire a fowle as Diogenes is, though my maiſter cogel my no bodie, as he threatned.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What Pſyllus, will the beaſte wag his winges to day?

sp.speaker: Pſyl.
sp.p: We ſhall heare: for here commeth Manes. Manes will it be?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Be, he were beſt be as cunning as a Bee, or elſe ſhortly he will not be at all.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: How is he furniſhed to fly, hath he feathers?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Thou art an aſſe, Capons, Geeſe & Owles, haue feathers. He hath found Dedalus old waxen wings, and hath beene peecing them this moneth, he is ſo broade in the ſhoulders. O you ſhall ſee him cut the ayre euen like a Tortoys.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.p: Me thinkes ſo wiſe a man ſhould not be ſo mad, his body muſt needes be to heauy.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Why, hee hath eaten nothing this ſeuennight but corke and feathers.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Tutch him Manes

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: He is ſo light, that he can ſcarſe keepe him from flying at midnight.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: See they begin to flocke, and behold my mayſter buſtles himſelfe to flye.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Yee wicked and beewtiched Atheneans, whoſe bodies make the earth to groane, and whoſe breathes infect the aire with ſtench. Come ye to ſee Diogenes fly? Diogenes commeth to ſee you ſinke? yee call me dog: ſo I am, for I long to gnaw the boanes in your skins. Yee tearme me an hater of menne: no, I am a hater of your maners. Your liues diſſolute, not fearing death, will proue your deaths deſperate, not hoping for life: what do you els in Athens but ſleepe in the day, and ſurfeite in the night: back Gods in the morning with pride, in the euening belly Gods with gluttonie. You flatter kings, & call them Gods: ſpeake trueth of your ſelues, & confeſſe you are diuels. From the Bee you haue taken not the honney, but the wax to make your religion, framing it to the time, not to the trueth. Your filthy luſte you colour vnder a courtly colour of loue, iniuries abroad vnder the title of pollicies at home, and ſecrete malice creepeth vnder the name of publick iuſtice. You haue cauſed Alexander to dry vp ſprings & plant Vines, to ſow roket and weede endiffe, to ſheare ſheepe, and ſhrine foxes. Al cōſcience is ſealed at Athens. Swearing commeth of a hot mettal: lying of a quick wit: flattery of a flowing tongue, vndecent talk of a mery diſpoſition. Al things are lawfull at Athens. Either you thinke there are no Gods, or I muſt think ye are no men. You build as though you ſhould liue for euer, and ſurfet as though you ſhould die to morow.

None teacheth true Phyloſophy but Ariſtotle, becauſe he was the kings ſchoolemaiſter. O times, O menne, O coruption in manners. Remember that greene graſſe muſt turne to dry hay. When you ſleep, you are not ſure to wake, and when you riſe, not certeine to lye downe, Looke you neuer ſo hie, your heads muſt lye leuell with your feete. Thus haue I flowne ouer your diſordered liues, and if you wil not amend your manners, I wil ſtudy to fly further from you, that I may be neerer to honeſty.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.p: Thou raueſt Diogenes, for thy life is different from thy words. Did not I ſee thee come out of a brothel houſe? was it not a ſhame?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: It was no ſhame to go out, but a ſhame to goe in.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: It were a good deede Manes, to beate thy maiſter.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: You were as good eate my maiſter.

sp.speaker: One of the people.
sp.p: Haſt thou made vs all fooles, and wilt thou not flye?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I tell thee vnleſſe thou be honeſt, I will flye.

sp.speaker: People
sp.p: Dog, dog, take a boane.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Thy father neede feare no dogs, but dogs thy father.

sp.speaker: People
sp.p: We wil tel Alexander, that thou reproueſt him behinde his back.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And I will tell him, that you flatter him before his face.

sp.speaker: People
sp.p: We wil cauſe al the boyes in the ſtreete to hiſſe at thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Indeede I thinke the Athenians haue their children ready for any vice, becauſe they be Athenians.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Why maiſter, meane you not to flye?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No Manes, not without wings.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Euery body will account you a lyar.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No, I warrant you: for I will alwaies ſay the Athenians are miſchieuous.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: I care not, it was ſport ynogh for me to ſee theſe old huddles hit home.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Pſyllus
sp.p: Come, let vs goe, and hereafter when I meane to raile vpon any body openly, it ſhall be giuen out, I will flye,

sp.speaker: Campaſpe ſola.
sp.p: Campaſpe, It is hard to iudge whether thy choice be more vnwiſe, or the chaunce vnfortunate. Doeſt thou preferre, but ſtay, vtter not that in woordes, which maketh thine eares to glow with thoughts. Tuſh better thy tongue wagge, then thy heart break. Hath a painter crept further into thy mind then a Prince? Apelles thē Alexander? Fond wench, the baſenes of thy mind bewraies the meanneſſe of thy birth. But alas, affection is a fyre which kindleth as well in the bramble as in the oake, & catcheth hold where it firſt lighteth, not where it may beſt burne. Larkes that mount aloof in the ayre, build their neaſtes below in the earth, and women that caſt their eies vpon kinges, may place their hearts vpon vaſſals. A needle will become thy fingers better then a Lute, and a diſtaffe is fitter for thy hand then a Scepter. Ants liue ſafely, til they haue gotten wings, & Iuniper is not blowne vp, till it hath gotten an hie top. The meane eſtate is without care, as long as it continueth without pride. But here commeth Apelles, in whom I woulde there were the like affection.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, the miſfortune I had with your picture, wil put you to ſome paines, to ſitte againe to be painted.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: It is ſmal paines for me to ſit ſtill, but infinit for you to draw ſtill.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: No Madame, to painte Venus was a pleaſure, but to ſhadowe the ſweete face of Campaſpe it is a heauen.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: If your tongue were made of the ſame fleſh that your heart is, your wordes would be as your thoughtes are, but ſuch a common thing it is amōgſt you to commēd, that oftentimes for faſhion ſake you cal thē beautifull, whom you know black.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: What might men doe to be beleeued?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Whet their tongues on their heartes.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: So they doe, and ſpeake as they thinke.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I would they did.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I would they did not.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Why, would you haue them diſſemble?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Not in loue, but their loue. But wil you giue me leaue to aske you a queſtion without offence.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: So that you wil aunſwere me an other without excuſe.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Whom do you loue beſt in the world.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: He that made me laſt in the world.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: That was a God.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I had thought it had beene a man. But whome do you honour moſt Apelles.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: The thing that is lykeſt you Campaſpe.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: My picture?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I dare not venture vpon your perſon. But come, let vs go in: for Alexander will thinke it long till we returne.

sp.speaker: Clytus.
sp.p:
We heare nothing of our Embaſſage, a colour
belike to bleare our eyes, or ticle our eares, or inflame our heartes. But what doth Alexander in the meane ſeaſon, but vſe for Tantara, Sol. Fa. La. for his harde couch, downe beddes, for his handfull of water, his ſtandinge Cup of wine?

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Clytus, I miſlike this new delicacie & pleaſing peace: for what els do we ſe now then a kind of ſoftnes in euery mans mind, Bees do make their hiues in ſoldiers helmets, our ſteedes furniſhed with foote clothes of gold, in ſteede of ſaddles of ſteele. More time to bee required to ſcoure the ruſt of our weapons, thē there was woōt to be in ſubdewing the countries of our enemies. Sithence Alexander fell from his harde armour to his ſofte robes beholde the face of his court, youthes that were woont to carry deuiſes of victory in their ſhieldes, engraue now poſies of loue in their ringes. They that were accuſtomed on trotting horſes to charge the enimy with a launce, now in eaſie coches ride vp & downe, to court Ladies: in ſteede of ſword and target to hazard their liues, vſe pen and paper to paint their loues. Yea, ſuch a feare and faintnes is growne in courte, that they wiſh rather to heare the blowing of a horne to hunt, thē the ſound of a trumpet to fight? O Phillip, wert thou aliue to ſee this alteration, thy men turned to womē, thy ſoldiers to louers, gloues worne in veluet, caps in ſteede of plumes in grauen helmets, thou wouldeſt ether die among them for ſorrow, or confound them for anger.

sp.speaker: Clitus,
sp.p: Ceaſe Permenio, leaſt in ſpeaking what becommeth thee not, thou feele what liketh thee not: truth is neuer without a ſcratcht face, whoſe tōgue although it cannot be cut out, yet muſt it be tied vp.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: It grieueth me not a little for Hepheſtion, whoe thirſteth for honour, not eaſe: but ſuch is his fortune & neereneſſe in friendſhip to Alexander, that he muſt lay a pillowe vnder his head, when he would put a targette in his hand.
But let vs draw in, to ſee how well it becomes them to tread the meaſurs in a daunce, that were wont to ſette the order for a march.

div.head: Actus quartus, Schaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I haue now Campaſpe, almoſt made an ende.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: You tolde me Apelles, you would neuer ende.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Neuer end my loue: for it ſhall be eternal.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: That is, neither to haue beginning nor ending.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: You are diſpoſed to miſtake, I hope you do not miſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What will you ſaye, if Alexander perceiue your loue?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I will ſay it is no treaſon to loue.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: But how if he wil not ſuffer thee to ſee my perſon?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Then will I gaſe continually on thy picture.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: That will not feede thy heart.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Yet ſhall it fill mine eye: beſides the ſweete thoughtes, the ſure hopes, thy proteſted faith, wil cauſe me to imbrace thy ſhadow continually in mine armes, of the which by ſtrong imagination I will make a ſubſtaunce.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Wel, I muſt be gon: but this aſſure your ſelf, that I had rather bee in thy ſhop grinding colours, then in Alexanders court, following higher fortunes.

div.p:
Fooliſh wenſh, what haſt thou done? that alas which cannot be vndone, and therefore I feare me vndone. But content is ſuch a lif, I care not for aboundance. O Apelles,
thy loue commeth from the heart, but Alexanders from the mouth. The loue of Kinges is like the blowinge of windes, whiche whiſtle ſometimes gentlye amonge the leaues, and ſtraight wayes turne the trees vp by the rootes: or fire which warmeth a farre off, and burneth neere hand, or the ſea, which maketh men hoyſe their ſeales in a flattering calme, and to cut their maſtes in a rough ſtorme. They place affection by times, by pollicie, by appointment, if they frowne, who dares cal them vnconſtant? if bewray ſecretes, who wil tearme them vntrue? if fall to other loues, who trembles not, if he call them vnfaithfull. In kinges there can be no loue, but to Queenes: for as neere muſt they meete in maieſtie, as they doe in affection. It is requiſite to ſtande aloofe from kinges loue, Ioue, and lightening.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Now Apelles, gather thy wits together: Campaſpe is no leſſe wiſe then fayre, thy ſelfe muſt bee no leſſe cunning then faithfull. It is no ſmall matter to be riuall with Alexander.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Apelles, you muſt come away quicklye with the picture, the king thinketh that now you haue painted it, you play with it.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: If I would play with pictures, I haue ynough at home.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: None parhaps you like ſo well.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: It may be I haue painted none ſo well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I haue knowne many fairer faces.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: And I many better boyes.

div.head: Actus quintus, Schaena prima.
div.stage: Diogenes, Syluius, Perim, Milo, Trico, Manes.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: I haue brought my ſons Diogenes, to be taught of thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: What can thy ſonnes doe?

sp.speaker: Silui.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee their qualities. Daunce ſirha.
How like you this? doth he well?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: The better, the worſer.

sp.speaker: Silui.
sp.p: The Muſicke very good.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: The Muſitions very badde, who onelye ſtudy to haue their ſtringes in tune, neuer framing their manners to order.

sp.speaker: Silui.
sp.p: Now ſhall you ſee the other. Tumble ſirha.
How like you this? why do you laugh?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: To ſee a wagge, that was born to break his neck by diſtinie, to practiſe it by arte.

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: This dogge will bite me I will not be with him.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Feare not boy, dogges eate no thiſtles.

sp.speaker: Perim.
sp.p: I maruel what dog thou art, if thou be a dog.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: When I am hungry, a maſtyue, and whē my belly is full a ſpaniell.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Doeſt thou beleeue that there are any gods, that thou art ſo dogged?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I muſt needs beleeue there are gods; for I think thee an enimie to them.

sp.speaker: Silui.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Becauſe thou haſt taught one of thy ſonnes to rule his legges, and not to follow learning, the other to bend his body euery way, and his minde no way.

sp.speaker: Perim.
sp.p: Thou doeſt nothing but ſnarle, and barke like a dogge.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: It is the next way to driue away a theefe.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Now ſhall you heare the third, who ſignes like a Nightingall.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I care not: for I haue heard a Nightingall ſing her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Sing ſirha.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Loe Diogenes, I am ſure thou canſt not doe ſo much.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But there is neuer a Thruſh but can.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: What haſt thou taught Manes thy man:

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: To be as vnlike as may be thy ſonnes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: He hath taught me to faſt, lye hard, & runne away.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: How ſayeſt thou Perim, wilte thou bee with him?

sp.speaker: Perim.
sp.p: I, ſo he will teache me firſt to run away.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Thou needeſt not be taught, thy legges are ſo nimble.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: How ſayeſt thou Milo, Wilte thou bee with hym?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Nay, holde your peace, he ſhal not.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: There is not roome enough for him and mee both to tumble in one tub.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Well Diogenes, I perceaue my ſonnes brooke not thy manners.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I thought no leſſe, when they knewe my vertues.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Farewel Diogenes, thou neededſt not haue ſcraped rootes, if thou wouldeſt haue followed Alexander.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Nor thou haue followed Alexāder, if thou hadſt ſcraped roots.

div.head: Actus quintus, Schaena ſecunda.
div.p: I feare me Apelles, that thine eies haue blabbed that, which thy tongue durſt not. What little regard hadſt thou, whilſt Alexander viewed the conterfeite of Campaſpe? thou ſtoodeſt gazing on her countenaunce. If he eſpie or but ſuſpect, thou muſt needes twice periſh with his hate, and thine owne loue. Thy pale lookes when he bluſhed, thy ſadde countenaunce, when hee ſmiled, thy ſighes, when he queſtioned, may breede in him a ieloſie, perchaunce a frenzye. O loue, I neuer before knewe what thou wert and nowe haſte thou made mee that I know not what my ſelfe am? Onely this I knowe, that I muſt endure intollerable pasſions, for vnknowne pleaſures. Diſpute not the cauſe wretch, but yeeld to it: for better it is to melt with deſire, then wraſtle with loue. Caſt thy ſelfe on thy carefull bedde, be content to lyue vnknowne, and die vnfounde. O Campaſpe, I haue painted thee in my heart, painted? nay, contrarye to myne arte, imprinted, and that in ſuche deepe Characters, that nothing can raſe it out, vnleſſe it rubbe thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: It ſhal go hard, but this peace ſhal bring vs ſome pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: Downe with armes, and vp with legges, this is a world for the nonce.

sp.speaker: Layis
sp.p: Sweet youths, if you knew what it were to ſaue your ſweete blood, you would not ſo fooliſhly go about to ſpend it. What delight can there be in gasſhing, to make foule ſcarres in faire faces, & crooked maimes in ſtreight legges? as though men being borne goodly by nature, would of purpoſe become deformed by folly, and all forſooth for a new found tearme, called valiaunt, a worde which breedeth more quarrells than the ſenſe can commendation.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: It is true Layis, a featherbed hath no fellowe, good drink makes good blood, and ſhal pelting wordes ſpill it?

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: I meane to enioy the world, and to draw out my life at the wiredrawers, not to curtall it off at the cutlers.

sp.speaker: Layis
sp.p: You may talke of warre, ſpeake bigge, conquer worldes with great wordes: but ſtay at home, where in ſteede of Alarums you ſhall haue daunces, for hot battailes with fierce men, gentle skirmiſhes with fayre women. Theſe pewter coates can neuer ſit ſo well as Satten dublets. Beleeue mee, you cannot conceiue the pleaſure of peace, vnleſſe you deſpiſe the rudenes of warre.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: It is ſo. But ſee Diogenes prying ouer his tub: Diogenes what ſayeſt thou to ſuch a morſell?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I ſay, I would ſpit it out of my mouth, becauſe it ſhould not poyſon my ſtomacke.

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt as thou art, it is no meate for dogges.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I am a dogge, and Philoſophy rates me from carion.

sp.speaker: Layis
sp.p: Vnciuill wretch, whoſe manners are anſwerable to thy calling, the time was thou wouldeſt haue had my company, had it not beene, as thou ſaydſt too deare.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p:
I remember there was a thing, that I repented
me of, and now thou haſte tolde it: indeede it was too deare of nothing, and thou deare to no bodie.

sp.speaker: Layis
sp.p: Downe villaine, or I will haue thy head broken.

sp.speaker: Mile.
sp.p: Will you couch?

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: Auant curre. Come ſweet Lays, let vs goe to ſome place, and poſſeſſe peace. But firſt let vs ſing, there is more pleaſure in tuning of a voyce, than in a volly of ſhotte.

sp.speaker: Milec.
sp.p: Now let vs make haſte, leaſt Alexander find vs here.

div.head: Actus quintus, Schaena quarta.
div.stage: Alexander, Hepheſtion, Page, Diogenes, Apelles, Campaſpe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Me thinketh Hepheſtion you are more melancholy than you were accuſtomed, but I perceiue it is all for Alexander. You can neither brooke this peace, nor my pleaſure, be of good cheare, though I winke, I ſleepe not.

sp.speaker: Hepheſt.
sp.p: Melancholy I am not, nor well content: for I know not how there is ſuch a ruſt crept into my bones with this long eaſe, that I feare I ſhall not ſcowre it out with infinite labours.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, yes, if all the trauailes of conquering the world will ſet either thy bodie or mine in tune, we will vndertake them. But what think you of Apelles? Did ye euer ſee any ſo perplexed? Hee neither anſwered directly to any queſtion, nor looked ſtedfaſtly vppon any thing. I holde my life the painter is in loue.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p:
It may be: for commonly we ſee it incident in artificers to be enamoured of their owne works, as Archidamus of his wodden doue, Pygmalion of his yuorie
Image, Arachne of his woddē ſwan, eſpecially painters, who playing with their owne conceſſes, now coueting to draw a glauncing eie, then a roling, now a wincking, ſtill mending it, neuer ending it, till they bee caught with it, and then poore ſoules they kiſſe the colours with their lippes, with which before they were loth to tainte theyr fingers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I will finde it out. Page, go ſpeedely for Apelles, wil him to come hither, and when you ſee vs earneſtly in talke, ſodainly crie out, Apelles ſhop is on fire.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Forget not your leſſon.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: I maruaile what your deuiſe ſhalbe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The euent ſhall prooue.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: I pitie the poore painter, if he be in loue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pitie him not, I pray thee, that ſeuere grauity ſet aſide, what doe you think of loue?

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: As the Macedonians doe of their hearb Beet, which looking yellow in the ground, and black in the hand, think it better ſeene than toucht.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But what doe you imagine it to be?

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: A word by ſuperſticiō thought a God, by vſe turned to an humor, by ſelf-will made a flattering madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You are too hard harted to think ſo of loue. Let vs go to Diogenes. Diogenes, thou maiſt think it ſomwhat, that Alexander commeth to thee againe ſo ſoone.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: If you come to learne, you could not come ſoone enough, if to laugh, you be come too ſoone.

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: It would better become thee to bee more curteous, and frame thy ſelfe to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: And you better to be leſſe, if you durſt diſpleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: What doſt thou think of the time we haue here?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: That we haue little and loſe much.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: If one be ſick what wouldſt thou haue him do?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Be ſure that he make not his phiſition his heire.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: If thou mighteſt haue thy will, how much groūd would content thee?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: As much as you in the end muſt bee contented withall.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What, a world?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No, the length of my bodie.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hepheſtion, ſhal I be a little pleſant with him?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: You may: but he wil be very peruerſe with you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It skills not, I cannot be angry with him. Diogenes, I pray thee what doeſt thou think of loue?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: A little worſer than I can of hate.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Becauſe it is better to hate the things, which make to loue, than to loue the things, which giue occaſion of hate.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, be not women the beſt creatures in the world?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Next men and Bees.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What doeſt thou diſlike chiefly in a woman?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: One thing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: That ſhe is a woman.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: In mine opinion thou wert neuer born of a woman, that thou thinkeſt ſo hardly of womē. But now cō meth Apelles, who I am ſure is as far frō thy thoughts, as thou art frō his cūning. Diogenes, I wil haue thy cabin remoued nerer to my court, becauſe I wilbe a philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And whē you haue done ſo, I pray you remoue your court further from my cabin, becauſe I wil not be a courtier.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But here commeth Apelles. Apelles, what peece of worke haue you now in hand?

sp.speaker: Apel.
